reference.shortdesc:
The choption element contains the content of the first cell in a choice table row. This content names the option that the user can take to complete the step.See my comment on choicetable: I don't think "names the option" is correct--should be "labels or describes the option" or close to. That is, you would never use the name "Option 1", you would use the label "Local server": both are distinct values (within the choice table), but one is an arbitrary name and one is a descriptive label.
Having said that, I suppose you might use "Option 1" if you write the command or info content such that it references the option name:
Having set the framitiz to "on" you may do Option 1 or Option 2 as shown in the choice table below.
So I guess it depends on whether you are writing the choice table as simple lookup table of options where the option labels are arbitrary or a state table where the option label reflects a specific state ("local server", "remote server").
Kris Eberlein, 31 October 2022
I agree that "names the option" is imprecise, but I think that it's the best that we can do. Shifting to "labels or describes the option" comes into conflict with 1) how we describe the <chdesc> element, and 2) what the <chhead> row provides. We're stuck with the element names – <choption> and <chdesc> – and also do not want to deviate too far from how these elements have been defined in the four versions of the DITA 1.x specifications. (I think the element names were poorly chosen, and our current rigor with short descriptions is highlighting that …)
Nonetheless, I'm setting the comment disposition to "Referred," so that we can discuss it at a TC meeting. Maybe someone else can come up with an acceptable way to describe what the <choption> element does.
